title: Authors and Citation

code: @Manual{,   title = {compareDFx: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel},   author = {Stephen Knapp},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0, https://skgithub14.github.io/compareDFx/},   url = {https://github.com/skgithub14/compareDFx}, }

what: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: {compareDFx} compares two data frames detailed reporting natively R MS Excel. MS Excel report multi-tab workbook color codes additions, deletions, changes ideal R users non-R users alike makes identifying data issues version differences quick easy.

title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: can install development version {compareDFx} like :

title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: Let’s assume df1 df2 two versions data set, df1 newer version. want know exactly values changed. Using two example data frames included {compareDFx}, df1 df2, walk {compareDFx} workflow.

title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: start loading {compareDFx} package defining data frames: {compareDFx} uses row’s unique ID evaluate changed two data frames. Unique IDs can consist one multiple columns. df1 df2, columns collectively make unique row ID id1 id2. means df1 two columns named id1 id2 df2 also two columns named id1 id2. Now can run comparison generate report Excel: Now multi-tab, color-coded MS Excel report summary statistics. data tabs report, cells df1 white background cells df2 grey background. text colored accordingly: Green text: cell values df1 different df2 Red text: cell values df2 different df1 Black text: cell values unchanged df1 df2 can explore file : Download comparison_report.xlsx can see, six tabs Excel workbook: summary: summary statistics summary column: column summary statistics data top-bottom: combined data displayed row df1 directly df2 counterpart. data left-right: data shown data top-bottom, df1 columns immediately left df2 counterpart. df1: raw data df1, reference df2: raw data df2, reference aren’t interested Excel report want work report R instead, can use output comparison object directly (see documentation get_comparison()).
code: library(compareDFx) data(df1) data(df2) # example data, df1  knitr::kable(df1) # example data, df2 knitr::kable(df2) id_cols <- c("id1", "id2") # run the comparison comparison <- get_comparison(df1, df2, id_cols)  # create the excel report create_comparison_excel(comparison, path = "comparison_report.xlsx")

title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: look far left data tabs (data top-bottom data left-right), see extra columns report useful comparison information: discrepancy: comparison status, can take one following values: "matched": row exactly matched df1 df2 "addition": row existed df1 "deletion": row existed df2 "changed": row id_cols matched df1 df2 least one column change "exact duplicate": row multiple occurrences either df1 df2. “Exact” means every value row matched perfectly duplicate copies. Exact duplicates can also marked "matched", "addition", "deletion", "changed". "ID duplicate (exact duplicate)": row multiple occurrences combination id_cols either df1 df2 exact duplicate (meaning least one non-ID value row different). ID duplicate marked "matched", "addition", "deletion", "changed" multiple value matches comparing df1 df2. user fix errors re-run comparison. "ID contains NA": row either df1 df2 NA value one id_cols. comparison procedure requires non-NA values id_cols therefore rows marked "matched", "addition", "deletion", "changed". user fix errors re-run comparison. source: column show data top-bottom sheet tells whether data row came df1 df2 next set columns hidden default, can shown clicking “+” top left corner worksheet: change group: discrepancy contains "changed" column populated arbitrary number links changed records df1 df2 exact dup cnt: discrepancy contains "exact duplicate" column gives number exact duplicates df1 df2 ID dup cnt: discrepancy contains "ID duplicate (exact duplicate)" column gives number ID duplicates df1 df2

title: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel
text: one way can use report find effective: "ID contains NA" values discrepancy column, start fixing raw data, re-run report. exist older version data (df2), maybe don’t need fix planning replacing old version new version (df1). "ID duplicate (exact duplicate)" values discrepancy column, investigate rows df1 /df2 ID values different entries columns. Similar step , problems older version (df2), maybe don’t need anything. Filter discrepancy column find entries containing "exact duplicate". Depending project, exact duplicates might okay , might want check correct number duplicates using exact dup cnt column. exact duplicates okay, remove raw data re-run report. Filter discrepancy column find entries containing "addition" "deletion". Check ID values correct. ID values incorrect misspelled, possible rows true additions deletions ID’s supposed match , case rows actually categorized "matched" "changed". ID values look good, confirm deleted rows supposed deleted added rows supposed added. Filter discrepancy column find entries containing "changed" verify changes expected. Fix “bad” changes raw data iteratively re-run report. cases, filtering change group column can helpful. Filter discrepancy column find entries containing "matched" verify rows supposed change versions. Fix issues re-run report iteratively.

what: compareDFx: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel — compareDFx-package
title: compareDFx: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel — compareDFx-package
text: Compares two data frames detailed reporting. report can analyzed natively R MS Excel. comparison analysis shows changes errors row column provides summary statistics. compareDFx can also compare data frames different columns column classes. MS Excel report multi-tab workbook color codes additions, deletions, changes can easily used non-R users.

title: compareDFx: Compare Data Frame Versions in R and MS Excel — compareDFx-package
text: Maintainer: Stephen Knapp stephen@knappconsultingllc.com (ORCID)

what: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
title: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
text: Creates multi-tab report comparing two data frames one tab element object returned get_comparison()

title: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
code: create_comparison_excel(   comparison,   path = "comparison_report.xlsx",   autoOpen = FALSE,   df_names = NULL )

title: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
text: comparison list returned get_comparison() path string, path Excel file written, default "comparison_report.xlsx" (must .xlsx suffix) autoOpen logical indicating whether Excel file automatically opened, default FALSE df_names optional character vector length two provides names data frames compared, first string vector df1 second string vector df2. provided, names appear Excel 'summary' tab. default NULL.

title: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
text: nothing

title: Create Excel report for comparing two data frames — create_comparison_excel
code: id_cols <- c("id1", "id2") comparison <- get_comparison(compareDFx::df1, compareDFx::df2, id_cols) #> Error in dplyr::left_join(., dup_cnt, by = c(id_cols, "source")): Can't join `x$id1` with `y$id1` due to incompatible types. #> ℹ `x$id1` is a <character>. #> ℹ `y$id1` is a <double>. path <- tempfile(pattern = "comparison_report", fileext = ".xlsx") create_comparison_excel(comparison, path) #> Error: object 'comparison' not found

title: Separate duplicated data frame rows from rows with no duplicates — find_dups
Separate duplicated data frame rows from rows with no duplicates — find_dups
text: df data frame without duplicated rows id_cols character vector column names form unique ID source string, name data source (usually "df1" "df2")

title: Separate duplicated data frame rows from rows with no duplicates — find_dups
text: names list four elements: exact_dups: rows duplicated every value, one distinct row exact_dups case column n list many occurences row df. id_dups: rows duplicated based id_cols values differed, column n contains many ID duplicates one ID exist df id_NA: rows NA value id_cols column no_dups: df id_dups row removed one copy exact_dups row.

title: Compare two data frames — get_comparison
text: Generates detailed comparison report two data frames

title: Compare two data frames — get_comparison
Compare two data frames — get_comparison
text: df1, df2 data frames compare id_cols column names df1 df2 make unique ID tolerance amount two numbers can differ considered equal, default 0.00001

title: Compare two data frames — get_comparison
text: named list elements: col_summary_simple: summary statistics columns col_summary_by_col: summary statistics column row_summary: summary statistics rows all_pivoted: comparison data displayed value df1 shown directly left df2 counterpart (pivoted view) comparison annotation columns all_tb: comparison data displayed row df1 shown directly df2 counterpart (top-bottom view) comparison annotation columns all_lr: comparison data displayed column df1 shown left df2 counterpart (left-right view) comparison annotation columns all_tb_change_indices: named list names data columns all_tb elements numeric vectors row indices changed df1 df2 column all_lr_change_indices: named list names data columns all_lr elements numeric vectors row indices changed df1 df2 column id_cols: columns df1 df2 form unique row ID cc_out: name list four elements: : logical indicating whether column names df1 df2 : character vector column names df1 df2 df1_only: character vector column names df1 df2 df2_only: character vector column names df2 df1 df1: raw data df1 df2: raw data df2

title: Compare two data frames — get_comparison
code: id_cols <- c("id1", "id2") comparison <- get_comparison(compareDFx::df1, compareDFx::df2, id_cols) #> Error in dplyr::left_join(., dup_cnt, by = c(id_cols, "source")): Can't join `x$id1` with `y$id1` due to incompatible types. #> ℹ `x$id1` is a <character>. #> ℹ `y$id1` is a <double>.
